column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.RoleAnnotation|roles
#Text=Mr.
#Text=Wang Guangya (China) (spoke in Chinese):\r
#Text=I wish at the outset to thank you, Mr.
#Text=President, for\r
#Text=initiating and organizing today's meeting.
#Text=I thank the\r
#Text=Secretary-General, Mr.
#Text=Kofi Annan, for his report on\r
#Text=the United Nations system-wide action plan\r
#Text=Our thanks go also to Under-Secretary-\r
#Text=General Jean-Marie Guehenno, Ms.
#Text=Rachel Mayanja,\r
#Text=Ms.
#Text=Noeleen Heyzer and other participants for their\r
#Text=presentations this morning.
#Text=In his report, the Secretary-General makes many\r
#Text=concrete recommendations for further implementation\r
#Text=by the United Nations system of resolution 1325\r
#Text=We welcome his recommendations and express\r
#Text=the hope that they can be effectively implemented.
#Text=This year marks both the fifth anniversary of the\r
#Text=adoption of Security Council resolution 1325 (2000)\r
#Text=and the tenth anniversary of the Fourth World\r
#Text=Conference on Women, held in Beijing.
#Text=Those\r
#Text=anniversaries lend particular significance to this open\r
#Text=debate on the question of women and peace and\r
#Text=security.
#Text=Five years ago the Security Council adopted\r
#Text=resolution 1325 (2000), which focused the international\r
#Text=community's attention on the question of women and\r
#Text=armed conflict and which provided guidance for the\r
#Text=endeavour to promote gender equality, protect women's\r
#Text=rights and expand the role played by women.
#Text=In the\r
#Text=five years since then - thanks to the efforts of the\r
#Text=Secretariat, the relevant peacekeeping operations, the\r
#Text=Special Adviser to the Secretary-General on Gender\r
#Text=Issues and Advancement of Women, the United\r
#Text=Nations Development Fund for Women and Member\r
#Text=States - much has been achieved in implementation of\r
#Text=resolution 1325 (2000).
#Text=The international community\r
#Text=now attaches greater importance to the role of women\r
#Text=in the settlement of armed conflicts, and the\r
#Text=Department of Peacekeeping Operations has mandated\r
#Text=that enhanced protection of women be a very important\r
#Text=component of the daily work of peacekeeping\r
#Text=operations.
#Text=Both at Headquarters and in many\r
#Text=peacekeeping operations, gender advisers have been\r
#Text=appointed.
#Text=At the recent High-level Plenary Meeting of the\r
#Text=General Assembly, world leaders once again stressed\r
#Text=the important role of women in the prevention and\r
#Text=resolution of conflicts and in peacebuilding and\r
#Text=reaffirmed their commitment to the full and effective\r
#Text=implementation of resolution 1325 (2000).
#Text=Five years on, when we look back on the road we\r
#Text=have travelled and forward to the path ahead, we can\r
#Text=see that a great deal of work remains to be done in\r
#Text=attaining the goals defined in resolution 1325 (2000).
#Text=First, we must strive to eliminate the root causes\r
#Text=of armed conflict and strengthen our conflict\r
#Text=prevention and early warning systems in order to create\r
#Text=an environment favourable to protecting women from\r
#Text=the harm that is caused by war.
#Text=In other words, we\r
#Text=must cure the disease by addressing its root causes.
#Text=Secondly, crimes of sexual assault must be\r
#Text=punished more harshly; violence against women must\r
#Text=be more seriously investigated and its perpetrators\r
#Text=must be brought to justice.
#Text=United Nations\r
#Text=peacekeeping operations must continue to pursue a\r
#Text=zero-tolerance policy to ensure strict compliance with\r
#Text=rules and adherence to standards.
#Text=Thirdly, women should be encouraged to\r
#Text=participate in peace processes at all stages.
#Text=In\r
#Text=particular, it is essential to ensure that they have\r
#Text=decision-making power so that the special needs and\r
#Text=the role of women will be reflected in conflict and\r
#Text=post-conflict processes.
#Text=Women are both the primary\r
#Text=victims of armed conflicts of all kinds and\r
#Text=indispensable participants in the resolution of any\r
#Text=conflict.
#Text=Their ardent yearning for peace enables them\r
#Text=to play a more important role in the promotion of peace\r
#Text=processes.
#Text=Fourthly, a summary should be prepared of\r
#Text=successful experiences in protecting women's rights,\r
#Text=with a view to sharing and actively replicating them.
#Text=Efforts should be made to enhance awareness of the\r
#Text=need to protect women's rights and to ensure that\r
#Text=words are translated into deeds.
#Text=Fifthly, work carried out on this issue by the\r
#Text=relevant bodies should be effectively coordinated.
#Text=All\r
#Text=parties should be encouraged to take steps with the\r
#Text=strength born of collective action and to make every\r
#Text=effort to achieve the best possible outcome.
#Text=Organs\r
#Text=such as the General Assembly and the Economic and\r
#Text=Social Council have been considering women's issues\r
#Text=for many years and have rich experience to offer.
#Text=The\r
#Text=Security Council should coordinate its activities with\r
#Text=theirs.
#Text=Women have played an important - indeed,\r
#Text=irreplaceable - role in the formation of human\r
#Text=civilization and the promotion of social development.
#Text=Progress for women is progress for all of humankind.
#Text=A popular Chinese saying has it that women hold up\r
#Text=half of the sky.
#Text=We hope that, through our common\r
#Text=efforts, mothers, wives and daughters will no longer\r
#Text=shed their tears at the horrors of war and that all our\r
#Text=sisters worldwide will lead happy and peaceful lives.
#Text=We believe that our world will then be a brighter and\r
#Text=more beautiful place.
